p: ReFED (Rethink Food waste through Economics and Data), a multi-stakeholder nonprofit committed to reducing food waste, identified 27 solutions, which were grouped into three categories: prevention, recovery, and recycling [ 7]. Although the associated incomes cannot be generalized for all countries, following these solutions, USD 100 billion is expected over 10 years in U.S. According to this program, the solutions focused on preventing waste production account for over 75% of the total, while 23% relate to waste recovery, and only 2% to recycling [ 5]. This proposal is consistent with the EPA (Environmental Protection Agency) “waste hierarchy,” which grades waste prevention as the most preferable option ( Figure 1) [ 8].
